comments: This is reported against 3.1.2 on Linux-GTK (which I'm developing in), but this hasn't been corrected in HEAD. And I believe I've had this same problem under Windows and 3.2. I get many NPEs when trying to change fonts using the Fonts and Colors preference page, including just to look at the current choices. The NPEs occur because def is null in the following test from in ColorsAndFontsPreferencePage.getText(j.l.Object): if (!ColorsAndFontsPreferencePage.equals(def .getCategoryId(), myCategory)) { Changing this test to: if (def != null && !ColorsAndFontsPreferencePage.equals(def .getCategoryId(), myCategory)) { prevents the NPE and seems to cause my expected behaviour. The trigger is that I have developed a plugin that specifies its own font definition in its plugin.xml: The text font used in the Ariadne Dossier view. I don't initialize this font to anything by default, so it should just pick up the default font (org.eclipse.jface.textFont). At least, I think that's right: I have to admit that I found the whole fonts-setting documentation to be a bit confusing.

Created an attachment (id=47648)
patch to ColorsAndFontsPreferencePage.java

Check that def isn't null.  Not sure if this is correct, but it at least prevents the NPE.

Please post the full stack trace for the NPE as well.

PW

As requested:

This problem still occurs in 3.3M3.  In tracing through the code, I've discovered that the problem is ultimately attributable to a documentation error: the example describing a <fontDefinition> in the documentation for the "org.eclipse.ui.fontDefinitions" extension point sets the 'defaultsTo' attribute to the incorrect "org.eclipse.jface.textFont".  This should have a lower-case `f'.

    <fontDefinition 
        id="org.eclipse.examples.userFont"
        label="User"
        defaultsTo="org.eclipse.jface.textFont"> <!-- should be textfont -->
        <description>
           The user font
        </description>
    </fontDefinition>

This is the source of the error, as I copied, pasted, and then modified this code.  As a result the call to ThemeRegistry.findFont() doesn't find the default font and returns null, leading to the symptoms described previously here.  

That said, a mis-configured font definition shouldn't cause walkbacks.  So patch #1 to ColorsAndFontsPreferencePage.java is correct in spirit, but we might want to handle the def==null case differently and return some different text.  And perhaps log a warning about the misconfiguration: this will occur on all platforms, and not just Linux-GTK.  

ColorsAndFontsPreferencePage$PresentationLabelProvider.getText() has a further problem in that it assumes that the element's categoryId is be non-null.  This is not a safe assumption as the example does not include a category either.

Created an attachment (id=54046)
Patch to example for org.eclipse.ui's fontDefinitions extension point schema

Patch to example for the (obsolete) org.eclipse.ui.fontDefinitions extension point to correctly refer to the correct 'org.eclipse.jface.textfont' default.
And I was mistaken about problems in the ColorsAndFontsPreferencePage$PresentationLabelProvider.getText() method when dealing with font-definitions lacking a category category.

Created an attachment (id=54068)
proect against NPE v02

Collapse Brian's patch and slight cleanup.

Kim, we should also be issuing a warning that a Font or Color definition has a bogus defaultsTo id ... where would be a good place?

PW
Paul's patch missed the change to also specify the font id of the example to use a lower-case `f'.  The example otherwise goes against the naming pattern used in all the current font definitions.

The case for that ID was fine.  i.e. there's no requirement that ids be all lower case ... just that we don't supply ids and then use bogus ones.

PW

Kim,

I think we should validate the defaultTo ids just after the themeRegistry is created in WorkbenchPlugin.

I'll put it together Friday.

PW
Moving to Kim for Kim and Paul to sort out
